eng: Weak if we were and foolish, not thus we failed, not thus; When that black Baal blocked the heavens he had no hymns from us (No direct equivalent in text)
They twisted even decent sin to shapes not to be named: Men were ashamed of honour; but we were not ashamed. (No direct equivalent in text)
Life was a fly that faded, and death a drone that stung; The world was very old indeed when you and I were young. (No direct equivalent in text)
Like the white lock of Whistler, that lit our aimless gloom, Men showed their own white feather as proudly as a plume. (No direct equivalent in text)
Round us in antic order their crippled vices came Lust that had lost its laughter, fear that had lost its shame. (No direct equivalent in text)
Science announced nonentity and art admired decay; The world was old and ended: but you and I were gay; (No direct equivalent in text)
Children we were our forts of sand were even as weak as we, High as they went we piled them up to break that bitter sea. (No direct equivalent in text)
A cloud was on the mind of men, and wailing went the weather, Yea, a sick cloud upon the soul when we were boys together. (No direct equivalent in text)
Fools as we were in motley, all jangling and absurd, When all church bells were silent our cap and bells were heard. (No direct equivalent in text)
I find again the book we found, I feel the hour that flings Far out of fish-shaped Paumanok some cry of cleaner things; (No direct equivalent in text)
To Edmund Clerihew Bentley (No direct equivalent in text)
G. K. C. CHAPTER I. (No direct equivalent in text)
We have found common things at last and marriage and a creed, And I may safely write it now, and you may safely read. (No direct equivalent in text)
Between us, by the peace of God, such truth can now be told; Yea, there is strength in striking root and good in growing old. (No direct equivalent in text)
The doubts that drove us through the night as we two talked amain, And day had broken on the streets e'er it broke upon the brain. (No direct equivalent in text)
The doubts that were so plain to chase, so dreadful to withstand Oh, who shall understand but you; yea, who shall understand? (No direct equivalent in text)
Not all unhelped we held the fort, our tiny flags unfurled; Some giants laboured in that cloud to lift it from the world. (No direct equivalent in text)
Of what colossal gods of shame could cow men and yet crash, Of what huge devils hid the stars, yet fell at a pistol flash. (No direct equivalent in text)
We have seen the City of Mansoul, even as it rocked, relieved Blessed are they who did not see, but being blind, believed. (No direct equivalent in text)
God and the good Republic come riding back in arms: (No direct equivalent in text)
But we were young; we lived to see God break their bitter charms. (No direct equivalent in text)
Yea, cool and clear and sudden as a bird sings in the grey, Dunedin to Samoa spoke, and darkness unto day. (No direct equivalent in text)
Or sane and sweet and sudden as a bird sings in the rain Truth out of Tusitala spoke and pleasure out of pain. (No direct equivalent in text)
And the Green Carnation withered, as in forest fires that pass, Roared in the wind of all the world ten million leaves of grass; (No direct equivalent in text)
This is a tale of those old fears, even of those emptied hells, And none but you shall understand the true thing that it tells (No direct equivalent in text)
A NIGHTMARE (No direct equivalent in text)
THE TWO POETS OF SAFFRON PARK (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "The man who sits in darkness, and who chose us all, chose me because I had all the crazy look of a conspirator because my smile went crooked, and my eyes were gloomy, even when I smiled."
fr: '-- L'homme de la chambre obscure m'a choisi, moi, parce que j'ai naturellement l'air d'un conspirateur, avec mes yeux tragiques, meme quand je souris, et mon rictus.'
extracted_text_eng:
The man who sits in darkness, and who chose us
all, chose me because I had all the crazy look of a conspirator because
my smile went crooked, and my eyes were gloomy, even when I smiled.

eng: "But there must have been something in me that answered to the nerves in all these anarchic men.'"
fr: '-- Il doit y avoir en moi, quelque chose de l'anarchiste...'
extracted_text_eng:
But
there must have been something in me that answered to the nerves in all
these anarchic men.

eng: "Haven't you sometimes felt it on a spring day? You know Nature plays tricks, but somehow that day proves they are good-natured tricks."
fr: '-- N'avez-vous pas eu un sentiment de ce genre, par une matinee de printemps ? La nature se plait a nous jouer des tours ; mais, un matin de printemps, on sent que ses tours sont de bons tours...'
extracted_text_eng:
Haven't you sometimes felt it on a spring day? You
know Nature plays tricks, but somehow that day proves they are
good-natured tricks.

eng: "How can I explain what my queer sympathy was? It didn't prevent my fighting him like hell!"
fr: '-- Remarquez que cette sympathie ne m'a pas empeche de le combattre comme l'enfer.'
extracted_text_eng:
How can I explain what my queer sympathy was? It
didn't prevent my fighting him like hell!

eng: "No, it's not an admiration of force, or any silly thing like that."
fr: '-- Ce n'est pas que j'aie une admiration pour la force ou quelque autre sottise de ce genre.'
extracted_text_eng:
No, it's not an admiration of force, or any silly thing like
that.

eng: "I don't understand a word of all that idea of his being the same man who gave us all our blue cards. It seems to make everything nonsense."
fr: '-- Qu'il soit l'homme aux cartes bleues, cela confond ma raison. Et il semble bien que cela confonde toute l'histoire.'
extracted_text_eng:
I don't understand a word of all that idea of his being
the same man who gave us all our blue cards. It seems to make
everything nonsense.

eng: "But I don't care who knows it, I always had a sympathy for old Sunday himself, wicked as he was. Just as if he was a great bouncing baby."
fr: '-- Mais -- peu m'importe qu'on le sache -- j'ai toujours eu de la sympathie pour lui, malgre sa mechancete. Comment expliquer cela ? Il me semble qu'il est un enfant, un grand enfant !'
extracted_text_eng:
But I don't care who knows it, I always had a
sympathy for old Sunday himself, wicked as he was. Just as if he was a
great bouncing baby.

eng: "I wish the beastly gas-bag would burst!"
fr: '-- je voudrais bien que cette outre volatile eclatat.'
extracted_text_eng:
I wish
the beastly gas-bag would burst!"

eng: "Do you believe all that tale about his being our man in the dark room? ~~~ Sunday would say he was anybody."
fr: '-- Croyez-vous au conte qu'il nous a fait ? Croyez-vous qu'il etait vraiment l'homme de la chambre obscure ? Dimanche est capable de tous les mensonges !'
extracted_text_eng:
Do you believe all that tale

eng: "But it isn't that that I mean. I can't wish old Sunday's balloon to burst because"

eng: "He talked to me in an ordinary way."
extracted_text_eng: He talked to me in an ordinary way.

eng: Very gradually and very vaguely he realised into what rich roads the carriage was carrying him.
fr: Vaguement, insensiblement presque, il s'apercut toutefois que la route etait belle, que la voiture franchissait la porte de pierre d'une sorte de parc, puis gravissait une colline, boisee a gauche a droite, mais soigneusement cultivee.

eng: He saw that they passed the stone gates of what might have been a park, that they began gradually to climb a hill which, while wooded on both sides, was somewhat more orderly than a forest.

eng: and when he found that he had to wear a sword, it stirred a boyish dream.
